title-group.subtitle: Empirical Support Informing Practice and Supervisor Training

article-meta.aff: 2University of California, Los Angeles, CA, USA
3California School of Professional Psychology, Alliant International University, Los Angeles, CA, USA
4University at Albany, State University of New York, USA

author-notes.corresp: Carol A. Falender, 1158 26th Street, #189, Santa Monica, CA 90403, USA Email: cfalende@ucla.edu

permissions.copyright-holder: Division of Counseling Psychology of the American Psychological Association

abstract.p: The purpose of this Major Contribution is to provide background knowledge and context for competency-based clinical supervision and to showcase a diversity of methodologically sound empirical approaches to study effective supervision, including multiculturally competent supervision, and comparative perspectives on supervision cross-culturally. The intent is to begin to provide the empirical data necessary to assist the supervisor in supporting supervisees’ development of the benchmark competencies and to provide direction for future training of supervisors. Specifically, the articles in this major contribution address competencies in clinical supervision and the Competency Benchmarks on three pivotal topics: empirical support defining effective supervision, innovative empirically based approaches to cross-cultural and international supervision, and an empirical analysis of feminist supervision in a multiculturally diverse group context. Each of the articles addresses particular Competency Benchmarks and provides prototypical models of rigorous research procedures to inform the practice of multicultural supervision and training of supervisors, and implications.

body.p: Clinical supervision is acknowledged as a distinct professional practice in psychology (Bernard & Goodyear, 2009; Falender et al., 2004; Fouad et al., 2009; Rodolfa et al., 2005). It is recognized as one of the top five activities of practicing psychologists (e.g., Norcross, Hedges, & Castle, 2002), is highly influential in the development of professional psychologists (Orlinsky, Ronnestad, & Collaborative Research Network of the Society for Psychotherapy Research, 2005), is the major form of transmission of the profession (Bernard & Goodyear, 2009), and ensures protection of the public (Association of State and Provincial Psychology Boards, 2003). We take the position that the importance of and need for competent clinical supervision is a sine qua non. Lack of attention to specific competencies from the Benchmarks (Fouad et al., 2009) and empirical study of effective or multicultural supervision implementation has provided inadequate direction for supervision practice and training. Therefore, the purpose of this Major Contribution is to spotlight prototypes of conceptually and methodologically sound research that investigates multicultural- and international-focused supervision practice. The Competency Benchmarks are the overarching umbrella that provide structure and direction for the individual contributions.

sec.title: Addressing Clinical Supervision
sec.p: As Westefeld (2009) pointed out in his article, “Supervision of Psychotherapy: Models, Issues, and Recommendations,” the last time The Counseling Psychologist devoted an entire issue to clinical supervision was in 1983. In the interim, Forrest (2010) described notable changes that have occurred in the field: the paradigm shift to competency-based supervision and training, and the emphasis on cultural and international contexts for supervision. This Major Contribution grew from the conviction that it is time to keep pace with the emergent changes in the science and practice of clinical supervision due to the competency movement and multicultural supervision, especially as they inform supervision practice and training

The advent of both Competency Benchmarks (Fouad et al., 2009) and competency-based clinical supervision (Falender & Shafranske, 2004; Farber & Kaslow, 2010; Kaslow, 2004) brings the opportunity to track the development of both supervisee and supervisor competence. However, a review of the literature found little to no research that provided the knowledge to implement the Competency Benchmarks for clinical supervision. The purpose of this Major Contribution is to provide background knowledge and context for competency-based clinical supervision and to showcase a diversity of methodologically sound empirical approaches to study effective supervision, including multiculturally competent supervision, and comparative perspectives on supervision cross-culturally. The intent is to provide empirical data necessary to assist the supervisor in supporting supervisees’ development of the Benchmark Competencies and to provide direction for future training of supervisors. More specifically, this major contribution attends to the following questions in the context of the Competency Benchmarks: (a) What is effective supervision (Ladany, Mori, & Mehr, 2013)? (b) How does the practice of supervision differ across cultures (Son, Ellis, & Yoo, 2013)? (c) How do we provide empirical data to inform systematic supervisor training in support of elucidating components of effective multicultural supervision (Burnes, Wood, Inman & Welikson, 2013; Wong, Wong, & Ishiyama, 2013)? In effect, the Benchmarks provide a bridge for these three questions.

We also address the often-ignored differentiation between supervisor and supervisee competencies and the elaboration of supervisor competencies past entry into practice. Currently, we have no empirical support for specific competencies of an effective supervisor beyond entry-level supervisors that was a product of the Competencies Conference (Falender et al., 2004), for which there is some support (Rings, Genuchi, Hall, Angelo, & Cornish, 2009), and those laid out in the Benchmarks (Fouad et al., 2009). The reality that no specific competencies are defined for clinical supervisors postlicensure directly influences the training of supervisors, a much-neglected area of pedagogy and study (e.g., Bernard & Goodyear, 2009), which is intrinsic to the integrity of competency-based supervision practice and to supervisee and client outcomes.

sec.title: Training in Supervision
sec.p: Notwithstanding the importance of supervision, there is a notable lack of formal training in the area of clinical supervision. Indeed, the majority of current supervisors have not received formal training in supervision (e.g., Bernard & Goodyear, 2009; Falender & Shafranske, 2004). The Task Force on Supervision of the Association of State and Provincial Psychology Boards (ASPPB) report expressed surprise at the lack of graduate-level training or formal coursework on supervision, both of which affect the training and practice of psychologists and protection of the public (ASPPB, 2003). This state of affairs has not changed substantially in the interim even though in 1996 the American Psychological Association (APA) began requiring accredited programs at a minimum to expose students to the supervision literature (C. L. Grus, personal communication, December 5, 2011). Recent data from the United States and Canada suggest that supervisees in the pipeline are not receiving adequate supervision training (e.g., in Canada, Hadjistavropoulos, Kehler, & Hadjistavropoulos, 2010; in the United States, Crook-Lyon, Presnell, Silva, Suyama, & Stickney, 2011; Lyon, Heppler, Leavitt, & Fisher, 2008). One factor to explain the lack of supervision training is the scarcity of empirically tested theories of and solid empirical knowledge about clinical supervision (Hunsley & Barker, 2011), probably because supervision practice developed independent of evidence-based treatments (Tebes et al., 2011). Authors of clinical supervision reviews have sharply critiqued existing research and advocated for quality empirical study of constructs related to both supervision process and supervision outcome (Ellis, D’Iuso, & Ladany, 2008; Ellis & Ladany, 1997; Inman & Ladany, 2008). Without sufficient knowledge, we will not be able to attain the Competency Benchmarks for clinical supervision (Fouad et al., 2009) or provide adequate training to supervisors who will prepare the next generation of professionals.

An apparent assumption of the Competency Benchmarks (Fouad et al., 2009) for supervision is that supervisors have attained all of the foundational and functional competencies laid out in the Benchmarks in their entirety. In the case of supervisees, competencies are acquired, with expected skills, knowledge, and attitudes for each level of development. The developmental progression of competencies provided by the Benchmarks for supervisees has received some support (Kamen,Veilleux, Bangen, VanderVeen, & Klonoff, 2010). As supervisees progress, supervisors determine levels of entrustability; that is, supervisors form a judgment about what clinical work and clients the supervisee can provide services to at his or her particular level of development and competency (ten Cate, 2005), a process we believe is facilitated by use of the Competency Benchmarks. In an editorial preceding the special competencies edition of Training and Education in Professional Psychology, the journal editors urged, “Stop talking about the competencies and start using them” (Bieschke et al., 2009, p. S3). The authors in this major contribution would add, “Start investigating supervision-related competencies to provide missing empirical support and knowledge required by the Competency Benchmarks (Fouad et al., 2009),” especially to inform supervisor training. The research presented herein is a step in that direction.

sec.title: The Competencies Movement and Supervision
sec.p: The competencies movement in psychology represents a convergence of multiple constituencies and perspectives including ethical principles regarding competence (APA, 2010), competency-based accreditation practices, credentialing, licensure (DeMers, 2009), and specialty certification (Rubin et al., 2007) providing a transition to a culture of competence (Roberts, Borden, Christiansen, & Lopez, 2005). The APA Commission on Accreditation requires programs to demonstrate means by which supervisees develop competence and how supervisees are informed of progress toward competency (APA, 2009). Movement toward competency-based approaches in psychology has been long in development (Kaslow, 2004; Nelson, 2007), but specific competencies were not delineated until the 2002 Competencies Conference: Future Direction in Education and Credentialing in Professional Psychology (Kaslow et al., 2004).

sec.title: Defining Competence
sec.p: A broadly adopted definition of competence that directed the Competencies Conference was drawn from the medical profession, “the habitual and judicious use of communication, knowledge, technical skills, clinical reasoning, emotions, values, and reflection in daily practice for the benefit of the individual and community being served” and depends on “habits of mind, including attentiveness, critical curiosity, self-awareness, and presence” (Epstein & Hundert, 2002, p. 227). For purposes of clinical supervision, training, and regulation of the profession, Rodolfa et al. (2005) added that competence is inferred when someone is “qualified, capable, and able to understand and do certain things in an appropriate and effective manner . . . [which] connotes that behaviors are carried out in a manner consistent with standards and guidelines of peer review, ethical principles and values of the profession, especially those that protect and otherwise benefit the public” (pp. 348-349).

Professional competence is described generally in the Ethical Principles of Psychologists and Code of Conduct (APA, 2010), specifically subsections of Section 2.0 Competence. Although the ethical standard provides parameters regarding necessity of practicing within one’s defined areas of competence, including multicultural and diversity competence, omitted is guidance as to the definition of competence beyond having or obtaining “training, experience, consultation, or supervision.” Clarity is lacking regarding the extent, breadth, and depth of supervisors’ competence, as it is difficult for the supervisor to be competent in every newly evolving specialty and area (Falender & Shafranske, 2007). Similarly, in Subsection 2.05 Delegation of Competence, the supervisor may delegate work to the supervisee to:
authorize only those responsibilities that such persons can be expected to perform competently on the basis of their education, training, or experience, either independently or with the level of supervision being provided; and see that such persons perform these services competently. (Standard 2.05 (2)(3), APA, 2010)
It is presumed that the supervisor is sufficiently competent to determine how to define what is expected to be performed competently and to ensure competent performance of the supervisee.

sec.title: The Competencies Cube
sec.p: A product of the Competencies Conference, The Competencies Cube, developed by Rodolfa et al. (2005), identified foundational and functional competencies of the professional psychologist. Foundational competencies, or requisite building blocks, include reflective practices and self-assessment, scientific knowledge and methods, relationships, ethical and legal standards and policy issues, individual and cultural diversity, and interdisciplinary systems. Functional competencies encompass the knowledge, skills, and attitudes essential to the practice of psychology, such as assessment, diagnosis, and conceptualization; intervention; consultation; research and evaluation; supervision and teaching; and management and administration. The third dimension of the cube is development: readiness for practicum, internship, and entry to practice. The Competencies Cube served as the foundation for the Competency Benchmarks Conference that defined essential components and behavioral anchors of each foundational and functional competency.

sec.title: Competency-Based Clinical Supervision
sec.p: Competency-based clinical supervision (Falender et al., 2004; Falender & Shafranske, 2004, 2007, 2008; Farber & Kaslow, 2010; Kaslow, 2004) and Competency Benchmarks (Fouad et al., 2009, pp. S21-S23) have provided blueprints for assessing, formatting, monitoring, and evaluating clinical training and supervision. The focus of these two documents is on both the competencies of supervisors (Falender et al., 2004; Fouad et al., 2009) and the developmental trajectory of competence for supervisees (Fouad et al., 2009; Kamen et al., 2010). Each of the articles in the Major Contribution addresses a particular aspect of translation of these general competencies to multicultural clinical supervision. The Competency Benchmarks served as an umbrella to organize these articles.

sec.title: What Is Effective Supervision?
sec.p: The role of the supervisor bears significant influence and power, but there has been relatively little exploration of its efficacy. The effectiveness of supervision encompasses not only changes in client outcome but also changes in therapist’s competencies (e.g., in session skills, professionalism). Empirical analysis has addressed proposed components of successful supervision: supervisory alliance and relationship variables, process of supervision including countertransference management and attention to diversity, and outcomes of the supervision process (Bernard & Goodyear, 2009).

Conversely, there is ample evidence of substandard supervision: perceived supervisory ethical violations (Ladany, Lehrman-Waterman, Molinaro, & Wolgast, 1999), “lousy” supervision practices (Magnuson, Wilcoxon, & Norem, 2000), poor models for supervisees (Ladany, 2004), and multiculturally incompetent treatment and supervision (Miville, Rosa, & Constantine, 2005). In fact, recent evidence suggests that many supervisors were providing inadequate supervision, which was moderately harmful to clients, and many supervisees experienced harmful supervision that was actually injurious to the supervisee (Ellis et al., 2009). Given that most supervisors are untrained in clinical supervision, issues pertaining to competence-based supervision and supervisor competencies seem especially timely.

Ladany et al. (2013) provide an invaluable addition with results that are directly related to supervisor competence and supervisor effectiveness in changing the supervisee. Ladany et al. reported on aspects associated with best and worst supervisors and demonstrated that even the best supervisors combine effective and ineffective supervisory behaviors: The ratio of these is the critical point, with effective supervisors using nearly 1½ times more effective behaviors than ineffective supervisors. The ineffective practices are all among those expected to be acquired during training as a supervisor, before licensure according to the Competency Benchmarks, for example: “Awareness of need for straightforward, truthful, and respectful communication in supervisory relationships” (Fouad et al., 2009, p. S22); “Reflects on supervision process, areas of strength and those needing improvement” (Fouad et al., 2009, p. S22); “Identifies goals and tasks of supervision related to developmental progression” (Fouad et al., 2009; p. S22); and “Tracks progress achieving goals and setting new goals” (Fouad et al., 2009, p. S21). In short, Ladany et al.’s results provide support for the Benchmarks as an important competence for clinical supervisors. Their research is a brilliant application of a rigorously mixed-method, within-subject research design that exemplifies the best practices for clinical supervision research (Ellis & Ladany, 1997).

sec.title: Multicultural Supervision
sec.p:
Effectiveness of multicultural supervision has been even more elusive. Despite the APA’s (2003) adoption of the Guidelines on Multicultural Education, Training, Research, Practice, and Organizational Change for Psychologists, APA Accreditation Standards (APA, 2009), and the APA Ethical Principles for Psychologists and Code of Conduct (APA, 2010), self-identified multiculturally competent psychologists reported a difference between self-assessed multicultural competency and their actual practice (Hansen et al., 2006; Sehgal et al., 2011). Goodyear, Bunch, and Claiborn (2006) decried the lack of attention to multicultural factors in supervision. Westefeld (2009) defined competent multicultural supervision citing Falender and Shafranske (2004):
The supervisor possesses “a working knowledge of the factors that affect worldview; . . . self-identity awareness and competence with respect to diversity in the context of self, supervisee, and client or family; competence in multimodal assessment of the multicultural competence of trainees . . . models diversity and multicultural conceptualizations throughout the supervision process; models respect, openness, and curiosity toward all aspects of diversity and its impact on behavior, interaction, and the therapy and supervision processes; initiates discussion of diversity factors in supervision. (p. 149)

The Competency Benchmarks incorporate diversity and cultural competence in supervision practice, for example: “Basic knowledge of and sensitivity to issues related to individual and cultural differences (i.e., the APA definition) as they apply to the supervision process and relationships” (Fouad et al., 2009, p. S22) and “Knowledge about the impact of diversity on all professional settings and supervision participants including self as defined by APA policy; beginning knowledge of personal contribution to therapy and to supervision” (Fouad et al., 2009, p. S22).

Because of supervisors’ difficulty understanding or empathizing with diverse and multiple cultural aspects of supervisees and clients (e.g., race, ethnicity, gender, and gender identity), supervisees report significant negative impact on the supervision relationship, self-doubt, and powerlessness (Jernigan, Green, Helms, Perez-Gualdron, & Henze, 2010, Singh & Chun, 2010). When culture is defined as the “dynamic and active process of constructing shared meaning, as represented by shared ideas, beliefs, attitudes, values, norms, practices, language, spirituality, and symbols, with acknowledgement and consideration of positions of power, privilege, and oppression” (Vargas, Porter, & Falender, 2008, p. 122), it broadens understanding for multicultural supervision.

The effectiveness of both multicultural and international supervisee supervision is enhanced by understanding both the supervisor’s and supervisee’s worldview, frames of reference, and views of tasks of supervision. For example, in a recent study of supervisors in South Korea, Bang and Park (2009) concluded that supervisors view teaching and supervision of supervisee’s personal issues as the full complement of supervision practice. However, in actual practice, passivity was experienced in supervisors’ actual exploration of supervisee personal issues, a result consistent with South Korean cultural values—personal issues are not discussed with those outside the family or closest friends. In an international student arena, Seo (2010) demonstrated the danger of cultural stereotypes as therapists are often cautioned against demonstration of emotion in therapy with Asian clients, but in practice, such demonstration was rated positively as a therapeutic technique with South Korean students in the United States. Thus, the empirical data contravene some commonly held beliefs about supervisees and supervisors from other cultures. Three articles in this Major Contribution address the Benchmarks listed above that pertain to multiculturally competent supervision (Burnes et al., 2013; Son et al., 2013; Wong et al., 2013).

Son et al. (2013) provided a meticulous comparative-descriptive analysis of clinical supervision between two diverse cultures: South Korean and the United States. The comparisons provide data that specifically address the Benchmarks Essential Component, “Understanding of other individuals and groups and intersection dimensions of diversity in the context of supervision practice, able to engage in reflection on the role of one’s self on therapy and in supervision” (Fouad et al., 2009, p. S22). Among the findings of interest were the divergent theoretical orientations (tendency toward cognitive behavioral among Americans and eclectic among South Koreans) that most U.S. participants were in doctoral programs whereas South Koreans were in master’s programs, but they did not vary in diversity of clinical settings or number of months of clinical experience. Most intriguing is the differences in formalized supervision and regulatory status for licensure, both exceptionally important issues in the United States and internationally—defining what is a psychologist. In short, Son et al. provide essential data that address the knowledge required for the supervisory Competency Benchmarks, specifically, for supervisors to engage appropriately supervisees from South Korea and the United States. Moreover, their research is both conceptually and methodologically rigorous—in essence, prototypical for cross-cultural descriptive studies (e.g., Ellis & Ladany, 1997). They employed a cogent reasoned argument, falsifiable research hypotheses, a priori statistical power analysis, relatively large and diverse samples from more than one culture, comparison groups, controlled Type I and II error rates, and optimal statistical procedures including effect size confidence intervals.

Most existent multicultural research has been critiqued for ethnocentricity of Western perspectives that view multicultural clients, increasingly all clients, through an invalid lens (Marsella & Pedersen, 2004). Although multicultural and diversity perspectives should be systematically infused in research and practice on clinical supervision (Ellis et al., 2008), much of the research and conceptualization exist in an ethnocentric frame despite the necessity for a global psychology lens (Pettifor, 2007). Competency-based approaches provide a potential remedy with recognition of underlying premises including movement from practice frames based on inviolate rules to universal human values (Pettifor, 2007). Although supervisors and/or supervisees may act as if there is simply one paradigm defining parameters for behavior, ethnopsychology and international perspectives reveal our ethnocentrism (Koss-Chioino & Vargas, 1999).

Wong et al. (2013) provide an investigation of understanding supervision competencies in an international context using an analysis of critical incidents. Using a critical incidence analysis approach derived from a qualitative research paradigm, the authors described specific incidents that shaped competencies related to the practice of multicultural supervision. Their results revealed roughly similar numbers reported for positive and negative incidents. Specifically, supervisory relationship, competence and professionalism in supervision and practice, cross-cultural competency, and personal attributes of the supervisor, especially support, flexibility, and openness, often-cited strengths of supervision (Bernard & Goodyear, 2009), were themes. Generally the importance of a humanistic-based mentoring model emphasizing the supervisory relationship seen through a multicultural lens was a major theme inferred from responses. Of great interest was that the participants experience personal growth through negative experience, thus highlighting the importance of not simply considering negative or positive events, but rather what the supervisory dyad does with each of these and how it affects the relationship. Negative critical incidences included incompetent multicultural supervision requiring culturally dissonant behavior (e.g., assertion), interpreting silence or gaze aversion as latent aggression, or engaging in conflict or discriminatory behavior. Harmful supervision involved unethical or dishonest supervisory behavior. These results add substantially by providing perspective on cross-cultural supervision inquiry and identification of positive practices.

As group supervision increases in frequency of occurrence (Riva & Cornish, 2008), multiple studies address the hindering factors (Enyedy et al., 2003) and the hazards of overlooking or avoiding discussion of multicultural events and misapplication of multicultural theory (Kaduvettoor et al., 2009). Burnes et al. (2013) provided a phenomenological study of group supervision process, one of the few investigations of group supervision (Bernard & Goodyear, 2009). A priori formulated clusters specifically addressed use of self in the supervisory relationship and the importance of supervision knowledge for structure and intervention in the process. Burnes et al.’s results provided necessary empirical data for supervisors to achieve the Competency Benchmarks, specifically, “Understanding of other individuals and groups and intersection dimensions of diversity in the context of supervision practice, able to engage in reflection on the role of one’s self on therapy and in supervision” (Fouad et al., 2009, p. S22). Their findings also provided “Knowledge about the impact of diversity on all professional settings and supervision participants including self as defined by APA policy”(Fouad et al., 2009, p. S22) and “Identifies impact of aspects of self in therapy and supervision” (Fouad et al., 2009, p. S22), and the associated Behavioral anchor “Demonstrates awareness of role of oppression and privilege on supervision process” (Fouad et al., p. S22), in addition to “Clearly articulates how to use supervisory relationships to leverage development of supervisees and their clients (Fouad et al., 2009, p. S22).

Collectively, the four perspectives offered by the research reported here represent a broadening of frames of reference and an ability to step back and reflect on alternate constructions of meaning, viewing culture and diversity as active, ongoing, and changing, and predicated by epistemologies or ways of understanding our world that are culturally based and play a vital role in supervision (Vargas et al., 2008). The articles on multicultural supervision in this Major Contribution provide innovative approaches to revisioning, reflecting on the social construction of all diversity in the context of oppression and societal expectations and roles, power, privilege, and empowerment. They also serve as prototypes of conceptually and methodologically sound research for future researchers in clinical supervision.

sec.title: Developing Competency-Based Supervision in Psychology: Implications
sec.p: In general, there exists a critical need within applied psychology to understand and promote supervision using a competency-based multicultural framework. In synthesizing calls from professional organizations both within and outside of counseling psychology, understanding supervisee and supervisor development from a competency-based framework as a guide to practice is a clear direction for supervision research and practice. The authors in this issue translated the need for study on competency-based supervision through a multicultural lens into empirical analysis in the form of qualitative and quantitative designs using the Competency Benchmarks as a criterion- referenced framework. Using a variety of methodologies, the studies contribute to the knowledge about multicultural approaches to achieve competency-based clinical supervision, effective supervision practice, and supervisor competencies, consistent with published Competency Benchmarks (Fouad et al., 2009).

sec.title: Developing Counseling Psychology Supervision and Training: Implications
sec.p: The articles in this Major Contribution provide valuable guidance for supervisors about effective supervision and the complexities of international, cross-cultural, and multicultural group supervision. We offer the six following implications.

list-item.p: Facilitating and engaging in the transformation to competency-based supervision remaining mindful of power, perspective, and the cultural and diversity relativity and context of competencies. The paradigm shift to competency-based, multicultural professional practice has already occurred. The next step is to develop an empirically derived knowledge base to expand supervisor knowledge, skills, and attitudes regarding the implementation of Competency Benchmarks as a metric for supervisee competency development. Subsequently, professionals need to implement multiculturally competent supervision as articulated in the Benchmarks (Fouad et al., 2009).

Encouraging methodological advances and new constructs in supervision research. The articles in this Major Contribution reinforce the need for innovative methodologies that continues to be a priority in the field (Gore & Leuwerke, 2008; Greenberg & Smith, 2008). Irrespective of the particular research design or methodology employed, investigators need to be cognizant about and address cultural, social justice, and diversity issues throughout the research process in clinical supervision. Specifically, such culturally intentional research would integrate multiculturalism and social justice beginning with inception-conceptualization of the phenomena of interest, through data collection, data analysis, and sharing findings. The research presented in this major issue may serve as prototypes of such research endeavors, as the authors use methodologically innovative processes and practices to understand supervision competencies.

Attending to multiple identities of client(s), supervisees, and supervisors. Scholars (e.g., Moradi, DeBlaere, & Huang, 2010) note the importance of centering intersecting, marginalized identities (e.g., people of color, and lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender [LGBT] people) within counseling psychology research and practice. Therefore, the need for supervision competency research to answer such a call from the field is critical. As suggested by the Competency Benchmarks, supervisors are responsible for attending to and initiating conversations about these identities and for preparing psychology trainees to address these issues in their respective advocacy, practice, and research settings.

Translating robust results into frameworks for training of supervisors. It is critical for competency-based supervision that empirical evidence can be used to train supervisors in didactic and applied settings. Such translation will attend to effective clinical supervision, multiple marginalized identities (e.g., LGBT people of color), and international worldviews. In addition, such training needs to attend to both the content and process of supervision to ensure that supervisors-in-training are attaining the Competency Benchmarks.

Conducting research on effectiveness of supervision training for supervisees in development and for more experienced supervisors. An area of research that continues to be underinvestigated is supervisor training and supervisor development, especially postlicensure (Bernard & Goodyear, 2009). Given the small number of researchers conducting programmatic investigations of clinical supervision, this is not surprising. Nevertheless, this is an urgent area of need—if we do not know how to best train and supervise clinical supervisors (e.g., Tebes et al., 2011), how can we ensure that the current and next generation of professionals will be multiculturally competent?

Increasing attention to cross-national studies of supervision practice, international competency standards, and evolving practices and guidelines in the international arena. The globalization of applied psychology is well under way (Gerstein, Heppner, Aegisdottir, Leung, & Norsworthy, 2009). Supervisors will increasingly encounter supervisees from diverse cultures and nationalities. Given the paucity of empirical knowledge about the similarities and uniqueness of clinical training and supervision in other countries and cultures, supervisors are likely to implement ethnocentric supervision—supervision that presumes that the approach of the host culture or nationality is equally viable for the supervisee and his or her culture or country of origin. We urge researchers to begin to fill in the gaps in the literature about clinical supervision and training in other countries and cultures, including supervisor training.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The articles in this Major Contribution provide an introduction to competency-based clinical supervision with multicultural competence as a priority. The articles are grounded in competency-based, methodologically innovative principles, and multicultural competence beyond an ethnocentric lens. The development of this Major Contribution is a step in attending to the role of Competency Benchmarks in clinical supervision, training, and professional development to provide direction in training of clinical supervisors.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Carol A. Falender is Adjunct Professor, Pepperdine Graduate School of Education and Psychology, Los Angeles, and Clinical Professor, Department of Psychology, University of California, Los Angeles. A Fellow of APA (Division 37), she is co-chair of the Society of Counseling Psychology’s (Division 17) Section for Supervision and Training. Her areas of teaching and scholarship include competency-based clinical supervision, supervisor training, and international supervision ethics.

Theodore R. Burnes, PhD, is an associate professor and member of the Multicultural-Community Psychology emphasis at the California School of Professional Psychology at Alliant International University in Los Angeles. He is the past chair of the Society of Counseling Psychology’s (Division 17) Section for Supervision and Training and an approved clinical supervisor. His teaching and research interests include mental health and wellness for LGBTQI people, multicultural clinical supervision, training in professional psychology, qualitative research methodologies, sexuality and sexual practice, and resilience-based trauma therapy. He also maintains a private practice.

Michael V. Ellis, PhD, is a professor and Director of the Division of Counseling Psychology, in the Department of Educational and Counseling Psychology at the University at Albany, SUNY. He is a Fellow of APA (Division 17), an Approved Clinical Supervisor, and recipient of the Supervision and Training Section’s 2010 Outstanding Professional Achievement Award. His teaching and research interests include multicultural clinical supervision, supervisor training, clinical judgment, and research methodology, psychometrics, and statistics. He also maintains a private practice.
